GlueFL: Reconciling Client Sampling and Model Masking for Bandwidth Efficient Federated Learning

Â 

Anonymous Authors1â€‰


Abstract

Federated learning (FL) is an effective technique to directly involve edge devices in machine learning training while preserving client privacy. However, the substantial communication overhead of FL makes training challenging when edge devices have limited network bandwidth. Existing work to optimize FL bandwidth overlooks downstream transmission and does not account for FL client sampling.

In this paper we propose GlueFL, a framework that incorporates new client sampling and model compression algorithms to mitigate low download bandwidths of FL clients. GlueFL prioritizes recently used clients and bounds the number of changed positions in compression masks in each round. Across three popular FL datasets and three state-of-the-art strategies, GlueFL reduces downstream client bandwidth by 27% on average and reduces training time by 29% on average.

â€ â€ footnotetext: 1Anonymous Institution, Anonymous City, Anonymous Region, Anonymous Country. Correspondence to: Anonymous Author <anon.email@domain.com>. Â 
Preliminary work. Under review by the Machine Learning and Systems (MLSys) Conference. Do not distribute.

1 Introduction

Federated learning (FL) moves machine learning (ML) training to the edge. In FL, edge clients communicate with a central server to collaboratively train a global model, while keeping client training data local. We focus on cross-device FL, in which there are many clients that are end-user devices. For example, companies like Google and Intel use cross-device FL for computer vision and natural language processing model training across customer devicesÂ Hartmann etÂ al. (2019); Yang etÂ al. (2018); Hard etÂ al. (2018).

One downside of FL is its network usage. This is especially problematic in cross-device FL, which relies on lower-bandwidth mobile or IoT devicesÂ Kairouz etÂ al. (2021). For example, Google Keyboard (Gboard), a virtual keyboard with over 1 billion installs, selects clients from millions of mobile devices to enhance its search query suggestionsÂ Yang etÂ al. (2018). In this type of application, clients usually have a diversity of device-to-server (upstream) and server-to-device (downstream) bandwidth. Clients that have either slow upstream or downstream bandwidth act as stragglers and slow down model training.

This heterogeneous bandwidth setting has attracted significant research, with a focus on reducing the communication cost of FL trainingÂ Chen etÂ al. (2021); Sattler etÂ al. (2019); Vargaftik etÂ al. (2022); Reisizadeh etÂ al. (2020); McMahan etÂ al. (2017). One important strategy is client sampling, which limits the number of clients that perform training in each roundÂ McMahan etÂ al. (2017); Luo etÂ al. (2022). Client sampling reduces both upstream and downstream bandwidth. However, a client that is not sampled gradually becomes stale: its local state diverges from the state of clients that have been sampled. The next time this client is sampled, the central server must therefore send a larger state update, increasing the downstream transmission overhead.

Another approach to reducing FL bandwidth usage is to apply a mask to the client gradients, such as a sparsification maskÂ Sattler etÂ al. (2019); Wangni etÂ al. (2018) or a parameter freezing maskÂ Chen etÂ al. (2021); Brock etÂ al. (2017). In traditional masking schemes, clients apply a mask to their local gradients and only transfer significant gradients to the server. This saves upstream bandwidth. Since each client generates the mask locally and independently, however, the entire model is usually updated at the end of a round and needs to be fully synchronized. In server masking schemes, such as Sparse Ternary Compression (STC)Â Sattler etÂ al. (2019) and Adaptive Parameter Freezing (APF)Â Chen etÂ al. (2021), the server uses a mask to compute the final model update. Since the server only partially updates the model, only a part of the model needs to be sent back to clients; this saves downstream bandwidth.

User sampling and masking approaches are typically considered as orthogonal, compatible approachesÂ Sattler etÂ al. (2019); Chen etÂ al. (2021). Though existing masking strategies are indeed empirically effective in full participation FL, we show that when client sampling is used they fail to decrease downstream bandwidth (Â§2). For example, with a 0.01 sample ratio and a masking compression ratio of 10%, a single client needs to download 75% of the global model on average. The reason downstream bandwidth increases is because of the staleness of local state at the clients. To see why, let us first consider the full participation case. Intuitively, since the global model is only partially updated by the server under masking, a client only needs to download this partial update and apply it to its local version of the model, saved from the previous round. With client sampling however, a typical client skips multiple rounds by not being sampled, and its local model state becomes stale. When the client is later sampled, it needs to download the new value of all parameters updated in the skipped rounds, which amounts to a large fraction of the model. This effect increases downstream bandwidth usage, voiding the benefits of server masking, and slowing down training when edge devices have limited download capacityÂ spe (2022).

To resolve the incompatibility between masking and client sampling, we propose GlueFL, a new FL training framework specifically designed to retain the benefits of masking when using client sampling. This compatibility is particularly important in cross-device FL deployments, which require both client sampling (full participation is impractical) and bandwidth savings due to mobile or IoT clients. To the best of our knowledge, GlueFL is the first masking design to address the downstream bandwidth bottleneck in cross-device FL with client sampling.

We design GlueFL with two new mechanisms to alleviate client staleness and to optimize downstream bandwidth requirements. First, we introduce sticky sampling (Â§3.1) to prioritize the most recently used clients, thereby reducing the number of stale clients in each update. Since recently selected clients have an up-to-date view of model parameters, they need to download smaller updates. We combine sticky sampling with a weighted central aggregation scheme to ensure that model updates remain unbiased, a requirement for convergence (Â§4). Sticky sampling is especially important in practical implementations that sample a small fraction of clients in each roundÂ Yang etÂ al. (2018).

Second, we propose a gradual mask shifting strategy (Â§3.2), to ensure that consecutive central model updates share a large number of changed parameters, while empirically preserving model convergence. This way, a newly selected client only has to synchronize a subset of the model, even after several rounds of not being sampled.

To sum up, we make three contributions:

  • â‹†â‹†\star

    We present an FL design called GlueFL, which is based on sticky sampling and mask shifting. These two new mechanisms alleviate the impact of client staleness in client sampling. Both techniques minimize downstream bandwidth in cross-device FL. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first work to combine masking with client sampling to reduce downstream bandwidth.

  • â‹†â‹†\star

    We analyse FL convergence under GlueFLâ€™s sticky sampling, and show that our proposed weighted aggregation preserves unbiasedness of updates and convergence.

  • â‹†â‹†\star

    We evaluate GlueFL empirically, and demonstrate downstream bandwidth and training time savings on three public datasets. On average, our evaluation shows that GlueFL spends 29% less training time with a 27% less downstream bandwidth overhead as compared to FedAvgÂ McMahan etÂ al. (2017), STCÂ Sattler etÂ al. (2019) and APFÂ Chen etÂ al. (2021).

2.2 Cross-device FL bandwidth characteristics

The cross-device FL setting relies on a large number of clients. In this case, some clients are likely to have an unreliable or slow network. For example, FigureÂ 1 shows the bandwidth distribution estimated by measurement labÂ Measurement Lab ((2022-06-01 â€“ 2022-07-01). We observe that around 20% of devices have a download bandwidth of at most 10Mbps. These devices can take at least 20s to download a typical model like ShuffleNet_V2Â Zhang etÂ al. (2018), which is specially designed for mobile devices and contains 5 million model parameters.

2.3 Limitations of Existing Masking Strategies

Prior work has proposed several masking strategies to reduce the amount of transferred data and alleviate low bandwidth issuesÂ Sattler etÂ al. (2019); Wangni etÂ al. (2018); Chen etÂ al. (2021); Brock etÂ al. (2017). To demonstrate how masking fails to optimize downstream bandwidth in FL with client sampling, we use STCÂ Sattler etÂ al. (2019), a popular server masking strategy, as a representative technique.

STC builds onÂ Stich etÂ al. (2018), a masking approach that selects and uploads the largest qğ‘q (e.g., 10%percent1010\%) absolute values in a clientâ€™s local gradients. In STC, this top-k sparsification technique is applied to both clientsâ€™ gradients and server updates111 For simplicity, we only consider the masking part of STCâ€”STC also includes quantization, an orthogonal technique that can be combined with sparsificationÂ Jiang & Agrawal (2018); Basu etÂ al. (2019) and will not change our conclusion, as quantization compresses both downstream and upstream communication.. AlgorithmÂ 1 shows this masking-only version of STC. For a single client sampled in both the current and last round, STC only has to update the weights covered by the server mask (lineÂ 1). However, note that a client that has not been sampled recently may have to update the entire model, as their local view of the model is stale. The reason is that server masks change in each round, and the client has to synchronize all updated model parameters since it last participated.

To measure the impact of model staleness on downstream bandwidth, we apply STC to FedAvg and conduct experiments on FEMNIST, using N=2,800ğ‘2800N=2,800 clients and a client sample size of K=30ğ¾30K=30. We try compression ratios of 10% and 20%222Smaller values led STC to require an unacceptable number of rounds to converge with a noticeable drop in convergence accuracy.. We examine both downstream and upstream bandwidth usage in each round. The results inÂ FigureÂ 2 show that upstream bandwidth is reduced when using a smaller compression ratio, as expected. However, a client still needs to download 70% of the global model on average. Clients with 10Mbps download bandwidth (Â§2.2) will take at least 14s to receive these changes. This imposes a high downstream bandwidth requirements on participating clients. In general, the more rounds that a client skips, the more updated model state it needs to download (FigureÂ 2b). As a result, the training bottleneck shifts to downstream communication. We expect these results to hold for other masking strategies as they similarly update different parts of the global model in each communication round. For example, in APFÂ Chen etÂ al. (2021), model parameters are frozen in some rounds but will then be updated again after the freezing period ends. The downstream bottleneck is therefore a general limitation across masking strategies.

2.4 Problem Setup

Our goal in GlueFL is to minimize the total expected downstream bandwidth of training, while retaining a low upstream bandwidth, and ensuring that the expected global training loss Fâ€‹(ğ°T)ğ¹superscriptğ°ğ‘‡F(\mathbf{w}^{T}) converges to a local minimum value, where ğ°Tsuperscriptğ°ğ‘‡\mathbf{w}^{T} is the aggregated global model after Tğ‘‡T rounds.

3 GlueFL Framework Design

GlueFL includes two components to decrease the downstream bandwidth during FL training: sticky sampling (FigureÂ 3) and mask shifting (FigureÂ 4). The newly designed sampling scheme allows some clients to be re-sampled in a short term and mask shifting restricts the mask from changing too fast. We elaborate on the design of each of these components in Â§3.1 and Â§3.2, before describing how to adapt other existing mechanisms in Â§3.3.

3.1 Sticky Sampling

Client sampling is the process of selecting Kğ¾K out of Nğ‘N clients in each round, to participate in computing the model update. With uniform sampling, each client participates in each round with a probability of K/Nğ¾ğ‘K/N. Thus, a client is expected to participate in training every N/Kğ‘ğ¾N/K rounds on average (See PropositionÂ 1 in AppendixÂ A). In cross-device FL systems, the value of Nğ‘N is often large, and Kğ¾K is small. For example, Gboard samples K=100ğ¾100K=100 clients in each round while there are millions of devicesÂ Yang etÂ al. (2018). This produces a low probability of participation in each round, which means that on average clients skip a large number of training rounds before being selected again. As we saw in Â§2.3, these long skips are responsible for local state staleness. Clientsâ€™ state must therefore be re-synchronized when they are selected, reducing the benefits of masking on downstream bandwidth.

GlueFL introduces sticky sampling to ensure that clients with an up-to-date local state are more likely to be selected. FigureÂ 3 illustrates sticky sampling and AlgorithmÂ 2 details it. The server maintains a smaller sticky group of clients ğ’®ğ’®\mathcal{S} with size Sğ‘†S, while the remaining clients form a non-sticky group, ğ’©âˆ–ğ’®ğ’©ğ’®\mathcal{N}\setminus\mathcal{S}. We randomly select Sğ‘†S clients to initialize ğ’®ğ’®\mathcal{S} in the beginning of training, and allow ğ’®ğ’®\mathcal{S} to evolve over time.

FigureÂ 3 (step 1) illustrates how in each FL training round, the server constructs its sampled set of clients ğ’¦ğ’¦\mathcal{K} from two sources; ğ’¦=ğ’âˆªâ„›ğ’¦ğ’â„›\mathcal{K}=\mathcal{C}\cup\mathcal{R}. It samples Cğ¶C clients to construct ğ’ğ’\mathcal{C} by sampling from the current sticky group ğ’®ğ’®\mathcal{S}. It samples (Kâˆ’C)ğ¾ğ¶(K-C) clients to construct â„›â„›\mathcal{R} by sampling from the non-sticky group, without replacement. All sampled clients ğ’¦ğ’¦\mathcal{K} participate in one round of training (AlgorithmÂ 2 lineÂ 2).

At the end of the round (FigureÂ 3 (step 2)), the server randomly selects (Kâˆ’C)ğ¾ğ¶(K-C) clients from ğ’®âˆ–ğ’ğ’®ğ’\mathcal{S}\setminus\mathcal{C} (the set of clients in the sticky group that did not participate in the latest round) and removes these clients from the sticky group (AlgorithmÂ 2 lineÂ 2). The server replaces these clients with (Kâˆ’C)ğ¾ğ¶(K-C) clients that were not sampled from the sticky group and that participated in the last update (â„›â„›\mathcal{R} in AlgorithmÂ 2).

Just as with uniform client sampling, sticky client sampling requires N/Kğ‘ğ¾N/K rounds to re-sample a client on average (see PropositionÂ 2 for details). However, a client selected with sticky sampling will join the sticky group and then have a higher probability of being selected in the next round than under uniform sampling, as long as CS>KNğ¶ğ‘†ğ¾ğ‘\frac{C}{S}>\frac{K}{N}. Since a client that exits the sticky group (by not being selected in the current round) is less likely to be selected than under uniform sampling (Kâˆ’CNâˆ’S<KNğ¾ğ¶ğ‘ğ‘†ğ¾ğ‘\frac{K-C}{N-S}<\frac{K}{N} when CS>KNğ¶ğ‘†ğ¾ğ‘\frac{C}{S}>\frac{K}{N}), we need to ensure that a sticky client has a higher expectation of being included during the next several rounds. This is because after several missed rounds, the whole model needs to be synchronized (see FigureÂ 2b). PropositionÂ 2 in Appendix A shows the probability for a client in the sticky group to be selected after rğ‘Ÿr rounds. We use this formula to select Sğ‘†S and Cğ¶C to ensure that this probability is higher than that of uniform sampling for a high enough value of rğ‘Ÿr.

Case Study. Consider a training run on FEMNIST with N=2,800ğ‘2800N=2,800 clients, K=30ğ¾30K=30, S=120ğ‘†120S=120, and C=24ğ¶24C=24 (our default experimental setup in Â§5.1). In this case, using the PropositionÂ 1 and PropositionÂ 2 in Appendix, we can compute the probability of client inclusion over the next 6 rounds for a client starting in the sticky group: 20.0%,15.0%,11.2%,8.5%,6.4%,4.8%percent20.0percent15.0percent11.2percent8.5percent6.4percent4.820.0\%,15.0\%,11.2\%,8.5\%,6.4\%,4.8\%. By contrast, uniform sampling re-samples clients with a probability of around 1.1%percent1.11.1\%.

With sticky sampling, clients that just participated in a round, and thus have an up-to-date state, are more likely to participate again in the short term. Such clients will therefore download smaller model updates. This synergizes with masking approaches that reduce the size of an update in each round. We show in Â§5 that for cross-device FL, where a large Nğ‘N and a small Kğ¾K are typical, masking approaches with sticky sampling significantly reduce downstream bandwidth usage.

However, sticky sampling also introduces new challenges during aggregation. As discussed in Â§2, the global update should provide appropriate representation for every client in expectationÂ Wang etÂ al. (2020); Mitra etÂ al. (2021); Wu etÂ al. (2021). Formally, the update should be an unbiased estimate of the FedAvg update computed on every client in round tğ‘¡t. That is: ğ”¼ğ’¦â€‹[Î”t]=âˆ‘i=1Npiâ€‹Î”itsubscriptğ”¼ğ’¦delimited-[]superscriptÎ”ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘subscriptğ‘ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptÎ”ğ‘–ğ‘¡\mathbb{E}_{\mathcal{K}}[\Delta^{t}]=\sum_{i=1}^{N}p_{i}\Delta_{i}^{t}. Under the FedAvg aggregation function (EquationÂ 2), since sticky clients are selected with higher probability, they would have a larger weight then non-sticky clients. To correct for this bias, GlueFL uses an inverse propensity weighted aggregation function. It assigns a different weight to updates from clients of different groups, corresponding to their importance parameter re-weighted by the inverse probability of selection. Updates from sticky group clients use the weight Î½i,st=SCâ€‹pisuperscriptsubscriptğœˆğ‘–ğ‘ ğ‘¡ğ‘†ğ¶subscriptğ‘ğ‘–\nu_{i,s}^{t}=\frac{S}{C}p_{i}, while non-sticky group clients use the weight Î½i,rt=Nâˆ’SKâˆ’Câ€‹pisuperscriptsubscriptğœˆğ‘–ğ‘Ÿğ‘¡ğ‘ğ‘†ğ¾ğ¶subscriptğ‘ğ‘–\nu_{i,r}^{t}=\frac{N-S}{K-C}p_{i}. 3.2 Mask Shifting

Sticky sampling allows clients in a sticky group to be sampled more frequently. However, sticky sampling alone is insufficient. As we have seen in FigureÂ 2, a client re-sampled after 10 rounds still needs to download around 50%-80% of the global model on average. This is because the masked updates of two successive rounds (e.g., Î”~tsuperscript~Î”ğ‘¡\tilde{\Delta}^{t} and Î”~t+1superscript~Î”ğ‘¡1\tilde{\Delta}^{t+1}) have little overlap.

We solve this issue by designing a gradual mask shifting strategy, that prevents the mask from changing too quickly while ensuring that the total compression ratio is maintained. FigureÂ 4 illustrates our mask shifting design. We construct a shared mask with compression ratio qsâ€‹hâ€‹rsubscriptğ‘ğ‘ â„ğ‘Ÿq_{shr} (with qsâ€‹hâ€‹r<qsubscriptğ‘ğ‘ â„ğ‘Ÿğ‘q_{shr}<q), which is represented using a bitmap shared with selected clients in Mtâˆˆğ”¹dsuperscriptğ‘€ğ‘¡superscriptğ”¹ğ‘‘M^{t}\in\mathbb{B}^{d} in round tğ‘¡t. Clients send their update for parameters in Mtsuperscriptğ‘€ğ‘¡M^{t}, as well as a qâˆ’qsâ€‹hâ€‹rğ‘subscriptğ‘ğ‘ â„ğ‘Ÿq-q_{shr} proportion of locally important parameters. The server will use Mtsuperscriptğ‘€ğ‘¡M^{t} as well as locally important parameters to calculate the model update, and to shift Mtsuperscriptğ‘€ğ‘¡M^{t} to obtain Mt+1superscriptğ‘€ğ‘¡1M^{t+1}, while keeping a large overlap between consecutive masks.

AlgorithmÂ 3 details the mechanism, with sticky sampling from AlgorithmÂ 2 used to select clients in linesÂ 3 andÂ 3. The server first synchronizes the global model ğ°tsuperscriptğ°ğ‘¡\mathbf{w}^{t} with sampled clients and distributes Mtsuperscriptğ‘€ğ‘¡M^{t} to them (lineÂ 3). In lineÂ 3, the client iğ‘–i calculates the shared local gradient Î”~i,sâ€‹hâ€‹rtsuperscriptsubscript~Î”ğ‘–ğ‘ â„ğ‘Ÿğ‘¡\tilde{\Delta}_{i,shr}^{t} as MtâŠ™Î”~itdirect-productsuperscriptğ‘€ğ‘¡subscriptsuperscript~Î”ğ‘¡ğ‘–M^{t}\odot\tilde{\Delta}^{t}_{i}, where âŠ™direct-product\odot sets those positions that are not covered by the masks to zero. Next, the algorithm computes unique local gradients Î”~i,uâ€‹nâ€‹itsuperscriptsubscript~Î”ğ‘–ğ‘¢ğ‘›ğ‘–ğ‘¡\tilde{\Delta}_{i,uni}^{t} by selecting a (qâˆ’qsâ€‹hâ€‹r)ğ‘subscriptğ‘ğ‘ â„ğ‘Ÿ(q-q_{shr}) proportion of the largest values in other (previously masked) positions, to provide more local information to the server (lineÂ 3). Finally, client iğ‘–i sends Î”~i,sâ€‹hâ€‹rtsuperscriptsubscript~Î”ğ‘–ğ‘ â„ğ‘Ÿğ‘¡\tilde{\Delta}_{i,shr}^{t} and Î”~i,uâ€‹nâ€‹itsuperscriptsubscript~Î”ğ‘–ğ‘¢ğ‘›ğ‘–ğ‘¡\tilde{\Delta}_{i,uni}^{t} to the server.

During aggregation, the central server uses sticky sampling importance weights Î½i,st,Î½i,rtsubscriptsuperscriptğœˆğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ‘ subscriptsuperscriptğœˆğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ‘Ÿ\nu^{t}_{i,s},\nu^{t}_{i,r} given in Â§3.1. The server first computes the shared update Î”~sâ€‹hâ€‹rtsuperscriptsubscript~Î”ğ‘ â„ğ‘Ÿğ‘¡\tilde{\Delta}_{shr}^{t} based on all client (weighted) updates, and the update based on unique local information by selecting the (qâˆ’qsâ€‹hâ€‹r)ğ‘subscriptğ‘ğ‘ â„ğ‘Ÿ(q-q_{shr}) proportion of largest overall (weighted) gradients (lineÂ 3). Formally, each quantity is computed as:

Î”~sâ€‹hâ€‹rtâ†âˆ‘iâˆˆğ’Î½i,stâ€‹Î”~i,sâ€‹hâ€‹rt+âˆ‘iâˆˆâ„›Î½i,rtâ€‹Î”~i,sâ€‹hâ€‹rtâ†superscriptsubscript~Î”ğ‘ â„ğ‘Ÿğ‘¡subscriptğ‘–ğ’superscriptsubscriptğœˆğ‘–ğ‘ ğ‘¡subscriptsuperscript~Î”ğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ‘ â„ğ‘Ÿsubscriptğ‘–â„›superscriptsubscriptğœˆğ‘–ğ‘Ÿğ‘¡subscriptsuperscript~Î”ğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ‘ â„ğ‘Ÿ\displaystyle\tilde{\Delta}_{shr}^{t}\leftarrow\sum_{i\in\mathcal{C}}\nu_{i,s}^{t}\tilde{\Delta}^{t}_{i,shr}+\sum_{i\in\mathcal{R}}\nu_{i,r}^{t}\tilde{\Delta}^{t}_{i,shr} (5)
Î”~uâ€‹nâ€‹itâ†tâ€‹oâ€‹p(qâˆ’qsâ€‹hâ€‹r)â€‹(âˆ‘iâˆˆğ’Î½i,stâ€‹Î”~i,uâ€‹nâ€‹it+âˆ‘iâˆˆâ„›Î½i,rtâ€‹Î”~i,uâ€‹nâ€‹it)â†superscriptsubscript~Î”ğ‘¢ğ‘›ğ‘–ğ‘¡ğ‘¡ğ‘œsubscriptğ‘ğ‘subscriptğ‘ğ‘ â„ğ‘Ÿsubscriptğ‘–ğ’superscriptsubscriptğœˆğ‘–ğ‘ ğ‘¡subscriptsuperscript~Î”ğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ‘¢ğ‘›ğ‘–subscriptğ‘–â„›superscriptsubscriptğœˆğ‘–ğ‘Ÿğ‘¡subscriptsuperscript~Î”ğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ‘¢ğ‘›ğ‘–\displaystyle\tilde{\Delta}_{uni}^{t}\leftarrow top_{(q-q_{shr})}\left(\sum_{i\in\mathcal{C}}\nu_{i,s}^{t}\tilde{\Delta}^{t}_{i,uni}+\sum_{i\in\mathcal{R}}\nu_{i,r}^{t}\tilde{\Delta}^{t}_{i,uni}\right) (6)

These updates are combined and update the global model (lineÂ 3). Finally, the shared mask is updated by selecting a share qsâ€‹hâ€‹rsubscriptğ‘ğ‘ â„ğ‘Ÿq_{shr} of parameters with the largest update values in the combined update (lineÂ 3). Since the new mask Mt+1superscriptğ‘€ğ‘¡1M^{t+1} will be used to compute Î”~t+1superscript~Î”ğ‘¡1\tilde{\Delta}^{t+1}, the overlap of two successive model updates Î”~tsuperscript~Î”ğ‘¡\tilde{\Delta}^{t} and Î”~t+1superscript~Î”ğ‘¡1\tilde{\Delta}^{t+1} is at least qsâ€‹hâ€‹rsubscriptğ‘ğ‘ â„ğ‘Ÿq_{shr}.

3.3 Adapting other Techniques to Work with GlueFL

We further improve the performance of GlueFL by adapting common FL techniques to sticky sampling and mask shiftingÂ Chen etÂ al. (2021); Han etÂ al. (2020); Tang etÂ al. (2019); Qian etÂ al. (2021); Wu etÂ al. (2018); Seide etÂ al. (2014).

Shared Mask Regeneration

Previous workÂ Chen etÂ al. (2021); Han etÂ al. (2020) showed that model parameters converge at different rates. Meanwhile, a parameter that has converged may become unstable in later rounds. For example, according to Chen etÂ al. (2021), it is possible that some 10% of parameters are unstable in both round tğ‘¡t and t+1ğ‘¡1t+1, while another 5% parameters are only unstable in round t+1ğ‘¡1t+1. In this case, a small (qâˆ’qsâ€‹hâ€‹r)ğ‘subscriptğ‘ğ‘ â„ğ‘Ÿ(q-q_{shr}) (e.g., 2%percent22\%) value will slow down convergence, as the shared mask fails to cover the gradients of the unstable 5%percent55\% of parameters and a large (qâˆ’qsâ€‹hâ€‹r)ğ‘subscriptğ‘ğ‘ â„ğ‘Ÿ(q-q_{shr}) (e.g., 10%percent1010\%) value incurs more bandwidth cost.

To address this, we use a small (qâˆ’qsâ€‹hâ€‹r)ğ‘subscriptğ‘ğ‘ â„ğ‘Ÿ(q-q_{shr}) value while re-generating the entire shared mask Mtsuperscriptğ‘€ğ‘¡M^{t} every Iğ¼I rounds. To regenerate, we set qsâ€‹hâ€‹r=0subscriptğ‘ğ‘ â„ğ‘Ÿ0q_{shr}=0 and update Mtsuperscriptğ‘€ğ‘¡M^{t} as tâ€‹oâ€‹pqsâ€‹hâ€‹râ€‹(Î”~uâ€‹nâ€‹it)ğ‘¡ğ‘œsubscriptğ‘subscriptğ‘ğ‘ â„ğ‘Ÿsuperscriptsubscript~Î”ğ‘¢ğ‘›ğ‘–ğ‘¡top_{q_{shr}}(\tilde{\Delta}_{uni}^{t}) (AlgorithmÂ 3, lineÂ 3). Although this process introduces more downstream overhead in the next few rounds, it speeds up training and reduces overall bandwidth.

Error-Compensation

Compression methods, such as quantization and sparsification, slow down model convergence due to the loss of information in client updatesÂ Tang etÂ al. (2019); Qian etÂ al. (2021); Wu etÂ al. (2018). Error-compensation is a technique to alleviate this problem, first proposed to accelerate convergence in 1-bit SGDÂ Seide etÂ al. (2014). The key idea is for clients to (1) remember their local compression error (the difference between their true update and what is actually sent to the server), and (2) add it into the next roundâ€™s computed local gradient before compression. In GlueFL, we apply error compensation as:

Î”itâ†Î”it+Î½iÏ†â€‹(t)Î½itâ‹…hiÏ†â€‹(t)â†superscriptsubscriptÎ”ğ‘–ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptÎ”ğ‘–ğ‘¡â‹…superscriptsubscriptğœˆğ‘–ğœ‘ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğœˆğ‘–ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptâ„ğ‘–ğœ‘ğ‘¡\Delta_{i}^{t}\leftarrow\Delta_{i}^{t}+\frac{\nu_{i}^{\varphi(t)}}{\nu_{i}^{t}}\cdot h_{i}^{\varphi(t)} (7)

where Î½itsuperscriptsubscriptğœˆğ‘–ğ‘¡\nu_{i}^{t} is the aggregation weight applied at step tğ‘¡t for client iğ‘–i (i.e., Î½i,stsuperscriptsubscriptğœˆğ‘–ğ‘ ğ‘¡\nu_{i,s}^{t} if they are in the sticky group, Î½i,rtsuperscriptsubscriptğœˆğ‘–ğ‘Ÿğ‘¡\nu_{i,r}^{t} otherwise; their exact values are defined in Â§3.1), Ï†â€‹(t)ğœ‘ğ‘¡\varphi(t) indicates the step-index when client iğ‘–i was last selected, and hiÏ†â€‹(t)superscriptsubscriptâ„ğ‘–ğœ‘ğ‘¡h_{i}^{\varphi(t)} the compensation vector for client iğ‘–i in round Ï†â€‹(t)ğœ‘ğ‘¡\varphi(t). After that, the client computes Î”~i,sâ€‹hâ€‹rtsuperscriptsubscript~Î”ğ‘–ğ‘ â„ğ‘Ÿğ‘¡\tilde{\Delta}_{i,shr}^{t} and Î”~i,uâ€‹nâ€‹itsuperscriptsubscript~Î”ğ‘–ğ‘¢ğ‘›ğ‘–ğ‘¡\tilde{\Delta}_{i,uni}^{t} (AlgorithmÂ 3, linesÂ 3-3). Then, the compensation vector is calculated as hit=Î”itâˆ’(Î”~i,sâ€‹hâ€‹rt+Î”~i,uâ€‹nâ€‹it)superscriptsubscriptâ„ğ‘–ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptÎ”ğ‘–ğ‘¡superscriptsubscript~Î”ğ‘–ğ‘ â„ğ‘Ÿğ‘¡superscriptsubscript~Î”ğ‘–ğ‘¢ğ‘›ğ‘–ğ‘¡h_{i}^{t}=\Delta_{i}^{t}-(\tilde{\Delta}_{i,shr}^{t}+\tilde{\Delta}_{i,uni}^{t}).

The reason for scaling with hiÏ†â€‹(t)superscriptsubscriptâ„ğ‘–ğœ‘ğ‘¡h_{i}^{\varphi(t)} in EquationÂ 7 is to ensure that client iğ‘–iâ€™s compensation is consistent with the aggregation in sticky sampling. As the compensation only applies to a clientâ€™s local gradient before masking, this optimization does not introduce extra bandwidth and improves convergence performance.

4 Convergence Analysis

From a theoretical perspective, we show that GlueFL without masking can achieve convergence at a rate of Oâ€‹(1/T)ğ‘‚1ğ‘‡O(1/\sqrt{T}) for smooth non-convex functions under two assumptions (Â§4.1). Â§4.2 states our result and their interpretation, with details in Â§C.

4.1 Assumptions

We make a standard assumption that clients sample a mini-batch in each local update such that the computed gradient is equal to the true gradient in expectationÂ Karimireddy etÂ al. (2020); Li etÂ al. (2020b); Wang etÂ al. (2020); Yang etÂ al. (2021); Wu etÂ al. (2022). That is, ğ”¼Î¾iâˆ¼ğ’Ÿiâ€‹âˆ‡fiâ€‹(ğ°,Î¾i)=âˆ‡Fiâ€‹(ğ°)subscriptğ”¼similar-tosubscriptğœ‰ğ‘–subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–âˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ°subscriptğœ‰ğ‘–âˆ‡subscriptğ¹ğ‘–ğ°\mathbb{E}_{\xi_{i}\sim\mathcal{D}_{i}}\nabla f_{i}(\mathbf{w},\xi_{i})=\nabla F_{i}(\mathbf{w}) for all workers iâˆˆ{1,â€¦,N}ğ‘–1â€¦ğ‘i\in\{1,\dots,N\} and the model ğ°âˆˆâ„dğ°superscriptâ„ğ‘‘\mathbf{w}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}, where Î¾isubscriptğœ‰ğ‘–\xi_{i} and ğ’Ÿisubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–\mathcal{D}_{i} represent the mini-batch and the local training set, respectively. We make two more assumptions:

Assumption 1 (Bounded Local Variance).

There exists a constant Ïƒ>0ğœ0\sigma>0, such that the variance of each local gradient estimator is bounded by,

We also assume that the local objective functions (i.e., F1,â€¦,FNsubscriptğ¹1â€¦subscriptğ¹ğ‘F_{1},\dots,F_{N}) and their derivatives are Lipschitz continuous.

Assumption 2 (Continuity and Smoothness).

The local objective functions are Lcsubscriptğ¿ğ‘L_{c}-continuous and Lssubscriptğ¿ğ‘ L_{s}-smooth.

Next, we show empirically that this is a favorable trade-off given the bandwidth savings enabled by sticky sampling (Â§5).

5 Experimental Evaluation

We evaluate GlueFL across several datasets and network distributions. Our goal is to answer three questions:

  1. Q1:

    What model accuracy does GlueFL achieve?

  2. Q2:

    How does GlueFL impact bandwidth usage?

  3. Q3:

    How quickly does the model converge with GlueFL?

5.1 Experimental Setup

We deployed GlueFL on a set of VMs in one data-center with a total of 14 NVIDIA Tesla V100 GPUs. To reproduce real-world heterogeneous client performance, we use FedScaleâ€™s client behavior trace and the NDT datasetÂ Measurement Lab ((2022-06-01 â€“ 2022-07-01) to simulate the availability pattern and bandwidth capacity of clients, respectively. To mitigate stragglers and offline clients, FedScale introduces an over-commitment (OC) variableÂ Bonawitz etÂ al. (2019) which we set to 1.3 in all experiments. That is, we sample 1.3Ã—K1.3ğ¾1.3\times K clients in each round and use the first Kğ¾K uploaded updates.

Datasets and Models

We use three datasets: FEMNISTÂ Caldas etÂ al. (2018), OpenImageÂ Kuznetsova etÂ al. (2020), Google SpeechÂ Warden (2018). The first two datasets are frequently used for image classification and consist of 640K and 1.3M colored images, respectively. Google Speech is a dataset with 105K speech samples. We partition the data using FedScaleâ€™s real-world non-iid client-data mappingÂ Lai etÂ al. (2022) and remove those clients that have fewer than 22 samples as the default setting in FedScale. In total, we use 2,80028002,800, 10,6251062510,625, and 2,06620662,066 clients in our experiments, respectively. The models we use are ShuffleNetÂ Zhang etÂ al. (2018) and MobileNetÂ Sandler etÂ al. (2018) for both FEMNIST and OpenImage, and ResNet-34Â He etÂ al. (2016) for Google Speech. Batch normalization layers in these models must be treated differently because some related parameters are non-trainable. We describe our approach for this in AppendixÂ D. We set the number of sampled clients K=30ğ¾30K=30, 100100100, and 303030 for FEMNIST, OpenImage, and Google Speech, respectively.

Baselines

We compare GlueFL with FedAvgÂ McMahan etÂ al. (2017), the most widely used FL algorithm with no model compression methods. We also compare GlueFL with STCÂ Sattler etÂ al. (2019) and APFÂ Chen etÂ al. (2021), which are the state-of-the-art sparsification and parameter freezing strategies, respectively.

Metrics

We measure the total data volume and total training time to address Q2 and Q3, respectively. We also analyze the downstream bandwidth and download time. For download time, we pick the slowest client in each round and sum up their download time. To address Q1, similar to OortÂ Lai etÂ al. (2021), we average the test accuracy over 5 rounds and report the results when the averaged accuracy first reaches the target accuracy.

Training Parameters

Clients perform 101010 local updates per round. We use PyTorchâ€™s SGD optimizer with a momentum factor of 0.9 for all tasks. For FEMNIST, OpenImage, and Google Speech, the initial learning rate is set to 0.01, 0.05, and 0.01, respectively, with a decay factor of 0.98 every 10 rounds. To obtain the best performance, we set the total mask ratio q=20%ğ‘percent20q=20\% for ShuffleNet, and q=30%ğ‘percent30q=30\% for MobileNet and ResNet-34 in STC. For APF, we set the threshold for effective perturbation, which reflects the compression ratio, to 0.10.10.1 for all tasks. The remaining STC and APF parameters are set to their optimal valuesÂ Sattler etÂ al. (2019); Chen etÂ al. (2021). For GlueFL, the default sticky group parameters are S=4â€‹Kğ‘†4ğ¾S=4K and C=4â€‹K/5ğ¶4ğ¾5C=4K/5. For ShuffleNet, the default mask shifting parameters are q=20%ğ‘percent20q=20\% and qsâ€‹hâ€‹r=16%subscriptğ‘ğ‘ â„ğ‘Ÿpercent16q_{shr}=16\%. For MobileNet and ResNet-34, we set q=30%ğ‘percent30q=30\% and qsâ€‹hâ€‹r=24%subscriptğ‘ğ‘ â„ğ‘Ÿpercent24q_{shr}=24\%. We use I=10ğ¼10I=10 to regenerate the shared mask every 10 rounds. We choose these values as they produce the best performance across most tasks.

5.2 Performance Results

Communication costs

TableÂ 2 lists the data volume and training time for FedAvg (baseline), STC, APF, and GlueFL (our framework). It shows that STC and APF outperform FedAvg as they require less bandwidth to reach the target accuracy, reducing volume by 8%percent88\% on average. However, STC and APF consume substantial downstream bandwidth. For example, when training MobileNet on FEMNIST, STC only takes 40 GB to upload gradients but uses 150 GB for downstream synchronization. GlueFL reduces downstream bandwidth (TableÂ 2): for OpenImage, GlueFL provides a saving of 15% compared with FedAvg, while for Google Speech GlueFL saves 42%. We further compare the performance of GlueFL with STC and APF. In each case, while consuming nearly the same amount of upstream bandwidth (note upstream bandwidth volume = TV-DV in TableÂ 2), GlueFL uses the least downstream bandwidth across all three datasets. For example, when training MobileNet on OpenImage, APF, STC, and GlueFL all consume around 900 GB to upload gradients. However GlueFL lowers download bandwidth by 11% and 26% as compared with STC and APF, respectively. This is because STC and APF do not bound the changes of masks in a communication round and the update size rapidly increases.

Wall-clock Time

TableÂ 2 indicates that downstream bandwidth is the bottleneck. For example, when training MobileNet on FEMNIST, FedAvg uses 32% of its total training time for model synchronization while STC uses 43%. GlueFL reduces total training time by reducing downstream bandwidth and saving download time, which speeds up the training by 15% and 26% as compared with STC and APF.

5.3 Sensitivity Analysis

We evaluate the influence of GlueFL parameters on training performance on FEMNIST with ShuffleNet and Google Speech with ResNet-34. Similar to Â§5.2, we use K=30ğ¾30K=30. When evaluating one parameter, we use defaults for the others (see Â§5.1). For each setting, we run GlueFL for 1,000 rounds and report the average test accuracy over 20 rounds with respect to the cumulative downstream bandwidth.

Effect of aggregation weights Î½i,stsubscriptsuperscriptğœˆğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ‘ \nu^{t}_{i,s} and Î½i,rtsubscriptsuperscriptğœˆğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ‘Ÿ\nu^{t}_{i,r}

FigureÂ 5 demonstrates the impact of two settings of aggregation weights on training performance: equal (i.e., Î½i,st=Î½i,rt=1/Ksubscriptsuperscriptğœˆğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ‘ subscriptsuperscriptğœˆğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ‘Ÿ1ğ¾\nu^{t}_{i,s}=\nu^{t}_{i,r}=1/K) and unbiased (see Â§3.1). Overall, unbiased aggregation weights lead to similar or better convergence speed for the same amount of cumulative downstream bandwidth usage. In the case of Google Speech, unbiased aggregation was able to achieve convergence while saving 41% of downstream bandwidth.

Sticky sampling parameters Sğ‘†S and Cğ¶C

FigureÂ 6 shows the impact of sticky group size Sğ‘†S on training performance. Typically, a larger sticky group size means more diverse training data for the sticky clients and indirectly better accuracy at the cost of more communication. It follows that choosing an appropriately large Sğ‘†S is important for optimizing performance. For instance, the S=120ğ‘†120S=120 setting for Google Speech reached the target accuracy with almost 20% less downstream communication compared with S=60ğ‘†60S=60. However, the same Sğ‘†S is unable to help GlueFL achieve a speedup for FEMNIST.

Next, we evaluate the impact of the sticky sampling parameter Cğ¶C (FigureÂ 7). Cğ¶C clients in the sticky group are sampled and (Kâˆ’C)ğ¾ğ¶(K-C) clients are replaced by clients from the non-sticky group. Across C=6,18,andâ€‹ 24ğ¶618and24C=6,18,\ \mathrm{and}\ 24 in FigureÂ 7, we do not observe a large improvement in accuracy for smaller Cğ¶C. By contrast, C=6ğ¶6C=6 adds 76% download bandwidth in each round as GlueFL is unable to capitalize on the savings from sticky sampling due to more new clients. This indicates that a large Cğ¶C does not harm accuracy and saves more bandwidth.

Mask shifting parameter qsâ€‹hâ€‹rsubscriptğ‘ğ‘ â„ğ‘Ÿq_{shr}

FigureÂ 8 shows the effect of the shared mask ratio qsâ€‹hâ€‹rsubscriptğ‘ğ‘ â„ğ‘Ÿq_{shr} on performance. On average, a higher value (qsâ€‹hâ€‹r=16%subscriptğ‘ğ‘ â„ğ‘Ÿpercent16q_{shr}=16\%) does not cause accuracy to drop substantially and is preferable as GlueFL uses the least downstream bandwidth to reach the convergence accuracy of FedAvg. This is because GlueFL optimizes mask shifting with shared mask regeneration and error compensation.

5.4 Network Environment

To further test our framework on high-throughput environments, we repeated the experiment in TableÂ 2 on commercial 5GÂ Narayanan etÂ al. (2021) and Google CloudÂ Mok etÂ al. (2021) with the default settings for GlueFL (see Â§5.1). Â FigureÂ 9 shows the total share of download, upload, and computation time for the three environments.

According to FigureÂ 9(a), transmission time remains a bottleneck in the end-user edge devices environment as shown in TableÂ 2. We attribute this to low-bandwidth clients. The ratio of download to upload time increases as we introduce compression. Since clients usually download faster than uploadÂ Measurement Lab ((2022-06-01 â€“ 2022-07-01); spe (2022): new clients in FedAvg spend 70% more time uploading than downloading the same-sized update. However, for STC and APF, download time takes on average 8% longer than upload, confirming the discussion in Â§2.3. To address this limitation, GlueFL saves downstream bandwidth and reduces download time by at least 42% as compared with other approaches. This is because clients in the sticky group are required to download less updates and are therefore less likely to become stragglers.

In 5G and intra-datacenter networks, computation dominates the per-round training time. Yet, straggler clients still exist and they ultimately determine the end-to-end training time.

5.5 Ablation Study

We described two optimization techniques in Â§3.3: shared mask regeneration and error-compensation. The first technique regenerates the shared mask Mtsuperscriptğ‘€ğ‘¡M^{t} every Iğ¼I rounds and the second technique adds a re-scaled compensation vector hiÏ†â€‹(t)superscriptsubscriptâ„ğ‘–ğœ‘ğ‘¡h_{i}^{\varphi(t)} to local updates Î”itsuperscriptsubscriptÎ”ğ‘–ğ‘¡\Delta_{i}^{t}. In this section, we conduct ablation studies to evaluate the effect of these techniques.

We run GlueFL on FEMNIST with ShuffleNet and Google Speech with ResNet-34. In each round, the server samples 30 clients out of 2,800 clients (for FEMNIST) and 30 clients out of 2,066 clients (for Google Speech). For each experiment, we run 1,000 rounds and measure the downstream bandwidth and test accuracy. While GlueFL consists of both sticky sampling and mask shifting, we only change the corresponding part in mask shifting and keep other training settings the same as Â§5.1.

Shared Mask Regeneration

As described in Â§3.3, we set qsâ€‹hâ€‹r=0subscriptğ‘ğ‘ â„ğ‘Ÿ0q_{shr}=0 and regenerate the shared mask as Mtâ†tâ€‹oâ€‹pqsâ€‹hâ€‹râ€‹(Î”~uâ€‹nâ€‹it)â†superscriptğ‘€ğ‘¡ğ‘¡ğ‘œsubscriptğ‘subscriptğ‘ğ‘ â„ğ‘Ÿsuperscriptsubscript~Î”ğ‘¢ğ‘›ğ‘–ğ‘¡M^{t}\leftarrow top_{q_{shr}}(\tilde{\Delta}_{uni}^{t}) every Iğ¼I rounds. A larger Iğ¼I value indicates that Mtsuperscriptğ‘€ğ‘¡M^{t} will be regenerated less frequently. We do not regenerate Mtsuperscriptğ‘€ğ‘¡M^{t} when I=âˆğ¼I=\infty.

In FiguresÂ 10a andÂ 10b, we plot results for three Iğ¼I values: 101010, 202020, âˆ\infty. Both figures show that setting I=10ğ¼10I=10 achieves the best overall performance, saving around 22% downstream bandwidth at the target accuracy for Google Speech. The impact of Iğ¼I on FEMNIST training in FigureÂ 10a is less pronounced but the I=10ğ¼10I=10 setting still has the best accuracy. Thus, in practice, we need to set an appropriate Iğ¼I value (e.g., 101010) to avoid a drop in accuracy.

Error-Compensation

In Â§3.3 we noted that error compensation can be used to accelerate convergence when applying compression methods in FL training. GlueFL re-scales the compensation vector hiÏ†â€‹(t)superscriptsubscriptâ„ğ‘–ğœ‘ğ‘¡h_{i}^{\varphi(t)}, following EquationÂ 7, to make it compatible with sticky sampling. In this section, we report on experiments for three error compensation settings: no compensation (None), compensation without re-scaling (EC), compensation with re-scaling (REC). The convergence results are shown in FiguresÂ 11a andÂ 11b. Both figures show that removing re-scaling from error compensation immediately breaks GlueFL and harms the convergence performance. This demonstrates that it is necessary to apply re-scaling with error compensation.

5.6 Availability and Stragglers

In Â§5.1 we discussed a default value of 1.3 for over-commitment. This means that GlueFL will sample 0.3Ã—K0.3ğ¾0.3\times K additional clients to mitigate stragglers and clients that might become unavailable (e.g., go offline). In this section, we explore different values and strategies in over-commitment for GlueFL.

In GlueFLâ€™s default setting, the over-commitment applies to both sticky group ğ’®ğ’®\mathcal{S} and non-sticky group ğ’©âˆ–ğ’®ğ’©ğ’®\mathcal{N}\setminus\mathcal{S}. The server will sample 0.3Ã—KÃ—(C/K)0.3ğ¾ğ¶ğ¾0.3\times K\times(C/K) and 0.3Ã—KÃ—(1âˆ’(C/K))0.3ğ¾1ğ¶ğ¾0.3\times K\times(1-(C/K)) additional clients from ğ’®ğ’®\mathcal{S} and ğ’©âˆ–ğ’®ğ’©ğ’®\mathcal{N}\setminus\mathcal{S}, respectively. However, as GlueFL only includes the fastest Kâˆ’Cğ¾ğ¶K-C clients in all sampled non-sticky clients to ğ’®ğ’®\mathcal{S} in each round, clients in ğ’®ğ’®\mathcal{S} are less likely to become stragglers. It follows that we can improve the over-commitment strategy by sampling fewer additional clients in ğ’®ğ’®\mathcal{S} while sampling more additional clients from ğ’©âˆ–ğ’®ğ’©ğ’®\mathcal{N}\setminus\mathcal{S}.

TableÂ 3a presents the results from using four over-commitment strategies for training ShuffleNet on FEMNIST. Similar to previous tasks: we select 30 clients out of 2,800 clients in each round and we choose another 9 (i.e., 0.3Ã—300.3300.3\times 30) clients for over-commitment. We report transmission volume and training time when the model reaches the target test accuracy of 73.3%. In the table, the OC strategy row of 10%percent1010\% means that 1 (i.e., 0.3Ã—30Ã—10%0.330percent100.3\times 30\times 10\%), and 8 (i.e., 0.3Ã—30Ã—(1âˆ’10%)0.3301percent100.3\times 30\times(1-10\%)) additional clients are sampled from ğ’®ğ’®\mathcal{S} and ğ’©âˆ–ğ’®ğ’©ğ’®\mathcal{N}\setminus\mathcal{S}, respectively. The results show that by choosing fewer additional clients from the sticky group, GlueFL consumes less training time without increasing the downstream bandwidth volume.

Next, we use the best setting of 10% (from TableÂ 3a) to evaluate different OC values. TableÂ 3b shows the results for OC values of 1.0 to 1.5. With increasing OC values, we find that training time decreases faster than downstream volume increases. As an example, when OC value is changed from 1.0 to 1.3, training time is decreased by 96% and downstream volume increases by 40%. However, increasing the OC value from 1.3 to 1.5 only reduces 11% training time while consuming 47% more downstream volume. In practice, one should set the OC value carefully to balance the trade-off between bandwidth and trainingÂ time.

6 Related Work

The synchronization bottleneck is an established problem in FL. Existing solutions fall into roughly two categories: (1) use client sampling to constrain the number of clients in each round; and, (2) compress model data with strategies like sparsification and parameter freezing.

Client sampling

FedAvg proposed a uniform sampling of clients to participate in each round. Uniform sampling has been shown to be biased, and multinomial distribution (MD) sampling was proposed to address this issueÂ Li etÂ al. (2020a). Clustered samplingÂ Fraboni etÂ al. (2021) reduced the variance of client update aggregation by improving client representation. OortÂ Lai etÂ al. (2021) introduced a practical client selection algorithm, which considers both data utility and clients speed.

Sparsification

The idea of sparsification is to send only the most informative gradients. GaiaÂ Hsieh etÂ al. (2017) transfers gradients whose absolute or relative values are larger than a given threshold. Stich et al.Â Stich etÂ al. (2018) proposed Top-K that, given a compression ratio, selects a fraction of gradients based on their absolute values to meet the ratio. STCÂ Sattler etÂ al. (2019) extended Top-K to FL training and also uses server-side compression.

Parameter freezing

Parameter freezing reduces bandwidth by freezing the gradients that converged. Brock et al.Â Brock etÂ al. (2017) proposed FreezeOut, which gradually froze the first few layers of a deep neural network that were observed to converge first. However, it has a coarse layer-based granularity and it degrades accuracy. APFÂ Chen etÂ al. (2021) improves on FreezeOut by freezing at a fine granularity and achieves a communication speed-up while preserving model convergence.

Our goal with GlueFL is to coherently combine client sampling with model compression. To our knowledge, we are the first to propose a combination that is unbiased, achieves high accuracy, and lowers downstream bandwidth usage.

7 Conclusions

We proposed GlueFL, a framework to optimize downstream bandwidth in cross-device FL. GlueFL uses sticky sampling for client selection and mask shifting for model compression to mitigate the low download bandwidth of FL clients. We also provide a theoretical convergence guarantee for GlueFL. In comparison with FedAvg, GlueFL achieves similar accuracy while decreasing total training time by 36% and uses 22% less downstream bandwidth. GlueFL also outperforms STCÂ Sattler etÂ al. (2019) and APFÂ Chen etÂ al. (2021).

Appendix A Analysis of Sampling Schemes

In this section, we provide a comparison between uniform sampling and sticky sampling to demonstrate the advantage of sticky sampling. We first analyze the probability that a client is re-sampled after rğ‘Ÿr rounds and then give the expected number of rounds for a client to be re-sampled.

A.1 Analysis on Uniform Sampling

Proposition 1.

Suppose a client is sampled at the current round. With uniform sampling, there is a probability of KNâ€‹(1âˆ’KN)râˆ’1ğ¾ğ‘superscript1ğ¾ğ‘ğ‘Ÿ1\frac{K}{N}(1-\frac{K}{N})^{r-1} that the client is sampled after rğ‘Ÿr rounds. On average, a client is sampled every N/Kğ‘ğ¾N/K rounds.

Proof.

The client is sampled with a probability of KNğ¾ğ‘\frac{K}{N}. The client has not been selected for the first (râˆ’1)ğ‘Ÿ1(r-1) rounds. Thus, this happens with a probability of KNâ€‹(1âˆ’KN)râˆ’1ğ¾ğ‘superscript1ğ¾ğ‘ğ‘Ÿ1\frac{K}{N}(1-\frac{K}{N})^{r-1}. Furthermore, the value of averaged sampled rounds is âˆ‘r=1âˆKNâ€‹(1âˆ’KN)râˆ’1â‹…r=N/Ksuperscriptsubscriptğ‘Ÿ1â‹…ğ¾ğ‘superscript1ğ¾ğ‘ğ‘Ÿ1ğ‘Ÿğ‘ğ¾\sum_{r=1}^{\infty}\frac{K}{N}(1-\frac{K}{N})^{r-1}\cdot r=N/K. âˆ

A.2 Analysis on Sticky Sampling

Proposition 2.

Suppose a client is sampled at the current round. Using sticky sampling, the client in the sticky group is sampled with a probability of 1(Nâˆ’S)â€‹Kâˆ’(Kâˆ’C)â€‹Sâ€‹(Kâ€‹(Nâ€‹Câˆ’Sâ€‹K)Sâ€‹(1âˆ’KS)râˆ’1+(Kâˆ’C)2â€‹(1âˆ’Kâˆ’CNâˆ’S)râˆ’1)1ğ‘ğ‘†ğ¾ğ¾ğ¶ğ‘†ğ¾ğ‘ğ¶ğ‘†ğ¾ğ‘†superscript1ğ¾ğ‘†ğ‘Ÿ1superscriptğ¾ğ¶2superscript1ğ¾ğ¶ğ‘ğ‘†ğ‘Ÿ1\frac{1}{(N-S)K-(K-C)S}(\frac{K(NC-SK)}{S}(1-\frac{K}{S})^{r-1}+(K-C)^{2}(1-\frac{K-C}{N-S})^{r-1}) after rğ‘Ÿr rounds. As expected, the client trains a model every N/Kğ‘ğ¾N/K rounds.

Proof.

In the sticky group, a client is sampled or moved to the non-sticky group with the probability of CSğ¶ğ‘†\frac{C}{S} and Kâˆ’CSğ¾ğ¶ğ‘†\frac{K-C}{S}, respectively. And, a client is sampled from the non-sticky group with probability Kâˆ’CNâˆ’Sğ¾ğ¶ğ‘ğ‘†\frac{K-C}{N-S}.

There are two strategies to sample a client that has participated in model training. First, it is sampled from the sticky group, where the probability is CSâ€‹(Sâˆ’KS)râˆ’1ğ¶ğ‘†superscriptğ‘†ğ¾ğ‘†ğ‘Ÿ1\frac{C}{S}(\frac{S-K}{S})^{r-1} after rğ‘Ÿr rounds. Second, it is sampled from the non-sticky group, indicating the client is moved out of the sticky group in the middle. Therefore, the probability is âˆ‘i=1râˆ’1(1âˆ’Kâˆ’CNâˆ’S)iâˆ’1â‹…Kâˆ’CNâˆ’Sâ‹…(Sâˆ’KS)râˆ’iâˆ’1â‹…(Kâˆ’CS)=(Kâˆ’C)2(Nâˆ’S)â€‹Kâˆ’(Kâˆ’C)â€‹Sâ€‹((1âˆ’Kâˆ’CNâˆ’S)râˆ’1âˆ’(Sâˆ’KS)râˆ’1)superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘Ÿ1â‹…superscript1ğ¾ğ¶ğ‘ğ‘†ğ‘–1ğ¾ğ¶ğ‘ğ‘†superscriptğ‘†ğ¾ğ‘†ğ‘Ÿğ‘–1ğ¾ğ¶ğ‘†superscriptğ¾ğ¶2ğ‘ğ‘†ğ¾ğ¾ğ¶ğ‘†superscript1ğ¾ğ¶ğ‘ğ‘†ğ‘Ÿ1superscriptğ‘†ğ¾ğ‘†ğ‘Ÿ1\sum_{i=1}^{r-1}(1-\frac{K-C}{N-S})^{i-1}\cdot\frac{K-C}{N-S}\cdot(\frac{S-K}{S})^{r-i-1}\cdot(\frac{K-C}{S})=\frac{(K-C)^{2}}{(N-S)K-(K-C)S}((1-\frac{K-C}{N-S})^{r-1}-(\frac{S-K}{S})^{r-1}). By summing up these two probabilities, we can obtain the desired result. Furthermore, similar to PropositionÂ 1, we can calculate the value of averaged sampled rounds. âˆ

A.3 Discussion

According to the proof of PropositionÂ 2, the probability of a client in the sticky group being sampled after rğ‘Ÿr rounds is greater or equal to CSâ€‹(Sâˆ’KS)râˆ’1ğ¶ğ‘†superscriptğ‘†ğ¾ğ‘†ğ‘Ÿ1\frac{C}{S}(\frac{S-K}{S})^{r-1}, which is the probability that it is still sampled from the sticky group. Then, for râˆˆ{1,â€¦,1+âŒŠ(logâ¡Câ€‹NSâ€‹K)/(logâ¡Sâ€‹(Nâˆ’K)Nâ€‹(Sâˆ’K))âŒ‹}ğ‘Ÿ1â€¦1ğ¶ğ‘ğ‘†ğ¾ğ‘†ğ‘ğ¾ğ‘ğ‘†ğ¾r\in\{1,\dots,1+\left\lfloor\left(\log{\frac{CN}{SK}}\right)/\left(\log\frac{S(N-K)}{N(S-K)}\right)\right\rfloor\}, CSâ€‹(Sâˆ’KS)râˆ’1ğ¶ğ‘†superscriptğ‘†ğ¾ğ‘†ğ‘Ÿ1\frac{C}{S}(\frac{S-K}{S})^{r-1} is greater or equal to KNâ€‹(1âˆ’KN)râˆ’1ğ¾ğ‘superscript1ğ¾ğ‘ğ‘Ÿ1\frac{K}{N}(1-\frac{K}{N})^{r-1}, the probability that a client is sampled after rğ‘Ÿr rounds in uniform sampling (PropositionÂ 1).

Appendix B Some Useful Lemmas

In this section, we provide two useful lemmas, which will apply to our subsequent analysis in Â§C. LemmaÂ 1 is used to present the progress in one single step in FL (Â§C.1) and LemmaÂ 2 is used to bound the gap between two successive global models (LemmaÂ 4).

Lemma 1 (Bottou etÂ al. (2018)).

Suppose a function â„‹â„‹\mathcal{H} is Lcsubscriptğ¿ğ‘L_{c}-continuous and Lssubscriptğ¿ğ‘ L_{s}-smooth. For any w,vâˆˆâ„dğ‘¤ğ‘£superscriptâ„ğ‘‘w,v\in\mathbb{R}^{d}, the following inequality holds for â„‹â„‹\mathcal{H}:

Appendix C Proof of TheoremÂ 2

In this section, we theoretically analyze the convergence rate of sticky-sampling in GlueFL on non-convex functions, under AssumptionsÂ 2 andÂ 1. The conclusion has been mentioned in TheoremÂ 2. The proof follows the same template as those of Bottou etÂ al. (2018); Karimireddy etÂ al. (2020); Wang etÂ al. (2020); Yang etÂ al. (2021), and proceeds as follows: (1) we use LemmaÂ 1 to bound the expected progress in each step (Â§C.1) by a sum of two terms. (2) We bound the first term through a bound on local updates (Â§Â C.3) and our unbiased aggregation. (3) We bound the second term by adapting a bound on the norm between two consecutive models to account for our aggregation weights (Â§C.4). (4) We use the bound on the expected progress in each step in a telescopic sum to bound the overall progress over training (Â§C.2).

We first present steps (1) and (4) in Â§Â C.1 andÂ C.2, which represent the high level articulation of the proof, before presenting the lower level results for steps (2) and (3) in Â§Â C.3 andÂ C.4.

C.1 Progress in one single step

We first bound the expected progress after one step of the model update. Appendix D Aggregation for Batch Normalization layers in GlueFL

A Batch Normalization (BN) layer contains five parameters: trainable weight, bias layers, and non-trainable summary statistics running_mean, running_var, and num_batches_tracked. While GlueFL updates trainable parameters (weight and bias) as all model parameters (AlgorithmÂ 3), non-trainable parameters (running_mean, running_var and num_batches_tracked) need to be treated differently. We perform the aggregation of these non-trainable parameters ğ¯ğ¯\mathbf{v} as follows:

Î”itâ†ğ¯it,Eâˆ’ğ¯it,0â†superscriptsubscriptÎ”ğ‘–ğ‘¡subscriptsuperscriptğ¯ğ‘¡ğ¸ğ‘–subscriptsuperscriptğ¯ğ‘¡0ğ‘–\displaystyle\Delta_{i}^{t}\leftarrow\mathbf{v}^{t,E}_{i}-\mathbf{v}^{t,0}_{i} (49)
ğ¯t+1â†ğ¯t+1Kâ€‹âˆ‘iâˆˆğ’¦Î”itâ†superscriptğ¯ğ‘¡1superscriptğ¯ğ‘¡1ğ¾subscriptğ‘–ğ’¦superscriptsubscriptÎ”ğ‘–ğ‘¡\displaystyle\mathbf{v}^{t+1}\leftarrow\mathbf{v}^{t}+\frac{1}{K}\sum_{i\in\mathcal{K}}\Delta_{i}^{t} (50)

where Î”itsuperscriptsubscriptÎ”ğ‘–ğ‘¡\Delta_{i}^{t} represents the local change of ğ¯tsuperscriptğ¯ğ‘¡\mathbf{v}^{t} on client iğ‘–i in round tğ‘¡t. Note that we do not perform re-weighting on Î”itsuperscriptsubscriptÎ”ğ‘–ğ‘¡\Delta_{i}^{t} as this produces the best empirical results. This aggregation rule is consistent with the FedScale implementationÂ Lai etÂ al. (2022).
